sen.j: 武内宿禰（たけうちのすくね・たけのうちの－・たけしうちの－、景行天皇14年（84年）？ - 仁徳天皇55年（367年）4月 (旧暦)？）は、『古事記』『日本書紀』で大和朝廷初期(景行天皇・成務天皇・仲哀天皇・応神天皇・仁徳天皇の5代の天皇の時期)に棟梁之臣・大臣として仕え、国政を補佐したとされる伝説的人物。
sen.e: TAKEUCHI no Sukune (TAKENOUCHI no -, TAKESHIUCHI no -, 84? - April 367?) is a legendary person recorded in "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), who is said to have served as Munemachi no Kimi or Oomi (chief administrator) and supported government in the period of early Yamato Dynasty (period of 5 Emperors, Emperor Keiko, Emperor Seimu, Emperor Chuai, Emperor Ojin, and Emperor Nintoku).

TAKEUCHI no Sukune (TAKENOUCHI no -, TAKESHIUCHI no -, 84? - April 367?) was a legendary person recorded in the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), who is said to have served as the Munemachi no Kimi or Oomi (Grand Minister) and advised the government during the early Yamato Dynasty (a period covering the reigns of Emperor Keiko, Emperor Seimu, Emperor Chuai, Emperor Ojin, and Emperor Nintoku).
sen.cmt: "is"→"was"Added "the""chief administrator"→"Grand Minister""supported"→"advised the""in the period of"→"during the"Added "a" "of 5 Emperors"→"covering the reigns of"
sen.e: TAKEUCHI no Sukune (his name can also be pronounced TAKENOUCHI no -, TAKESHIUCHI no -, 84? - April 367? (old lunar calendar)) was a legendary person recorded in the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), who is said to have served as the Munemachi no Kimi or Oomi (Grand Minister) and advised the government during the early Yamato Dynasty (a period covering the reigns of Emperor Keiko, Emperor Seimu, Emperor Chuai, Emperor Ojin, and Emperor Nintoku).
sen.cmt: (old lunar calendar)補足

sen.j: 紀氏・巨勢氏・平群氏・葛城氏・蘇我氏などの中央諸豪族の祖とされるが詳細は不明。
sen.e: He is regarded as an ancestor of several central ruling families such as Ki clan, Kose clan, Hegri clan, Katsuragi clan, and Soga clan, but details are unknown.
He is regarded as an ancestor of several central ruling families such as the Ki clan, the Kose clan, the Hegri clan, the Katsuragi clan, and the Soga clan, but details are unknown.
sen.cmt: Added "the" before clan namesCapitalized 'c'
sen.e: He is regarded as an ancestor of several central ruling families such as the Ki clan, the Kose clan, the Hegri clan, the Katsuragi clan, and the Soga clan, but details are unknown.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、建内宿禰とも表記される。
sen.e: He is also written as 建内宿禰.
sen.cmt: 文字自体が話題となっている為そのまま表記しました。
sen.e: His name is sometimes written using the characters 建内宿禰.
sen.cmt: "He is also"→"His name is sometimes""as"→"using the characters" - although the kanji are the main topic, I don't think the sentence as a whole has much relevance for the typical English speaker
sen.e: His name is sometimes written using the characters 建内宿禰.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 別称：御食津大神（ミケツノオオカミ）（気比神）、高良玉垂神（コウラタマタレノカミ）
sen.e: Other names: Miketsu no Okami (God of Kehi), Kora Tamatare no Kami.
Other names: Miketsu no Okami (God of Kehi), Kora Tamatare no Kami.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Other names: Miketsu no Okami (God of Kehi), Kora Tamatare no Kami.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 記紀の登場人物では最も長命の人間で、一人の人物とは考えられず、親子が何代かが同じ名前をついだもの、あるいは個人ではなくある種の人間集団の事跡を一人の人物の事柄に仮託して描かれたものではないかとする仮説も唱えられているが、確かではない。
sen.e: He has the longest life span in characters recorded in Kiki ("Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki"), and since he can't be thought as one person, hypothesis such as several succeeding generations passed down the same name, or it is not an individual but achievements of some kind of group of people were gathered into one person when it was recorded, have been advanced, but it is not sure.

He has the longest life span of any character recorded in the "Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki", and since he can't be thought as one person, hypothesis advanced include several succeeding generations passing down the same name, or the achievements of several people being amalgamated into one person when it was recorded, but this is not certain.
sen.cmt: "in characters"→"of any character" Added "the""Kiki ("Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki")"→""Kojiki" and "Nihonshoki"" "have been advanced"→"advanced" and moved"such as"→"include""passed"→"passing""it is not an individual but achievements of some kind of group of people were gathered into one person"→"the achievements of several people being amalgamated into one person""it is not sure"→"this is not certain"
sen.e: He has the longest life span of any character recorded in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki - too long for a single person, which led some people to hypothesize that he may have been created as an imaginary character representing a certain group of people; however, this remains uncertain.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 安本美典は古事記や日本書紀に記された古代の天皇の存在そのものは信じられるが、皇位を父子で継承した事と在位年数が信頼できないという説を唱えている。
sen.e: Biten YASUMOTO advance a theory that the existence of ancient Emperors recorded in Kojiki and Nihonshoki itself can be believed, but the matter that Imperial Throne was succeeded from father to his son and the years of reign can't be trusted.

Biten YASUMOTO proposes a theory that the existence of ancient Emperors recorded in the Kojiki and Nihonshoki itself can be believed, but the practice of the Imperial Throne being passed down from father to son and the lengths of reigns can't be trusted.
sen.cmt: "advance"→"proposes"Added "the""matter that"→"practice of the""was succeeded"→"being passed down"Deleted "his""years"→"lengths"Made "reign" plural
sen.e: Biten YASUMOTO argues that although ancient emperors described in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki are likely to be historical figures, descriptions about the practice of the imperial throne being passed down from father to son and the lengths of the emperors' reigns are highly dubious.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: その例証のひとつとして、ひとりの天皇の在位年数を実際より長くしてしまったため、武内宿禰のような何代もの天皇に仕えた者の年齢が異常に長くなったとしている。
sen.e: He states as an illustration that since the years of one Emperor was lengthened from actual length, age of a person such as TAKEUCHI no Sukune, who served to several succeeding Emperors, have been lengthened abnormally, too.

He states as an illustration that since the length of one Emperor's reign was increased from its actual length, the life span of a person such as TAKEUCHI no Sukune, who served several successive Emperors, would have to have been abnormally lengthened accordingly.
sen.cmt: "years"→"length"Made "Emperor" possessiveAdded "reign""lengthened"→"increased"Added "its""age"→"the life span"Deleted "to""succeeding"→"successive"Added "would have to"Moved "abnormally"", too"→"accordingly"
sen.e: He maintains that the length of each emperor's reign was made longer than its actual length, which caused the life spans of persons, such as TAKEUCHI no Sukune, who served several successive emperors, to be abnormally long.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 成務天皇と同年同日の生まれという。
sen.e: He is said to have been born on the same date with Emperor Seimu.
He is said to have been born on the same date as Emperor Seimu.
sen.cmt: "with"→"as"
sen.e: He is said to have been born on the same date as Emperor Seimu.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 景行天皇の時に北陸・東国を視察し、蝦夷の征討を進言。
sen.e: At the time of Emperor Keiko, he inspected Hokuriku region and Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly Kanto region) and advised to subjugate Emishi (people in northern part of Japan)

During the reign of Emperor Keiko, he inspected the Hokuriku region and Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) and proposed subjugating the native Emishi people of northern Japan.
sen.cmt: "At the time"→"During the reign"Added "the""advised to subjugate"→"proposed subjugating the"Added "native""(people in northern part of Japan)"→"people of northern Japan"Added full stop
sen.e: During the reign of Emperor Keiko, he inspected the Hokuriku region and Togoku (the eastern part of Japan, particularly the Kanto region) and proposed subjugating the native Emishi people of northern Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 成務天皇3年（133年）に大臣となる。
sen.e: In 133, he became Oomi.
In 133, he was made Oomi.
sen.cmt: "became"→"was made"
sen.e: In 133, he was made Oomi.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 神功皇后の朝鮮出兵を決定づけ、忍熊皇子らの反乱鎮圧にも功があった。
sen.e: He clinched the expedition of army to Korea by Empress Jingu, and also contributed to the suppression of rebellion by Oshikuma no Miko.
He took part in Empress Jingu's invasion of Korea and succeeded in suppressing a rebellion by Prince Oshikuma.
sen.cmt: "clinched the expedition of army to Korea by Empress Jingu"→"took part in Empress Jingu's invasion of Korea""also contributed to the suppression of"→"succeeded in suppressing a"
sen.e: He took part in Empress Jingu's invasion of Korea and succeeded in suppressing a rebellion by Prince Oshikuma.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 応神天皇の時、渡来人を率いて韓人池を造る。
sen.e: At the time of Emperor Ojin, he lead toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) and made Karahito no ike-Pond.

During the reign of Emperor Ojin, he led a group of toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) in constructing Karahito no ike-Pond.
sen.cmt: "At the time"→"During the reign""lead"→"led"Added "a group of""and made"→"in constructing"
sen.e: During the reign of Emperor Ojin, he led a group of toraijin (people from overseas, especially from China and Korea, who settled in early Japan and introduced Continental culture to the Japanese) in constructing Karahito no ike-Pond.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: また、甘美内宿禰から謀反の讒言を受けたが、探湯（くかたち）を行って濡れ衣を晴らした。
sen.e: Also, he was slandered by Umashiuchi no Sukune as a rebel, but cleared that false charge by Kukatachi (a way of judging true or false in ancient Japan by putting hand in boiled water, if true, the hand won't be burned).

Also, he was was accused of treason by Umashiuchi no Sukune, but cleared his name by Kukatachi (a way of judging honesty in ancient Japan where a suspect's hand was placed in boiling water and, if unharmed, the suspect was telling the truth).
sen.cmt: "slandered by Umashiuchi no Sukune as a rebel"→"was accused of treason by Umashiuchi no Sukune""that false charge"→"his name"Rewrote explanation of Kukatachi
sen.e: Also, he was accused of treason by Umashiuchi no Sukune, but cleared his name by Kukatachi (a way of judging honesty in ancient Japan where a suspect's hand was placed in boiling water and, if unharmed, the suspect was telling the truth).
sen.cmt: was重複削除

sen.j: 仁徳天皇50年（362年）が『書紀』に現われる最後。
sen.e: The year 362 is his last appearance in "Shoki" (Nihonshoki).
The year 362 is his last appearance in the "Shoki" (Nihonshoki).
sen.cmt: Added "the"
sen.e: The year 362 is his last appearance in the "Shoki" (Nihonshoki).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 『公卿補任』『水鏡』は同55年（367年）、『帝王編年記』所引一書は同78年（390年）に没したといい、年齢についても280歳・295歳・306歳・312歳・360歳などの諸説がある。
sen.e: "Kugyobunin" (directory of court nobles) and "Mizukagami" (The Water Mirror) states that he died in 367 and quotations in "Teio Hennenki" states that he died in 390, and there are various theories about age of his death such as 280, 295, 306, 312, 360, and so on.
sen.cmt: 所引一書→読み、定訳不明です
sen.e: The "Kugyobunin" (Directory of Court Nobles) and the "Mizukagami" (The Water Mirror) state that he died in 367 and quotations in "Teio Hennenki" state that he died in 390, and his age at death is variously given as 280, 295, 306, 312, 360, and so on.
sen.cmt: Added "The"Capitalised 'd', 'c' and 'n'Added "the"Deleted 's'"there are various theories about age of his death such as"→"his age at death is variously given as"
sen.e: The "Kugyobunin" (Directory of Court Nobles) and the "Mizukagami" (The Water Mirror) state that he died in 367 and quotations in "Teio Hennenki" (the Chronicle of emperors) state that he died in 390, and his age at death is variously given as 280, 295, 306, 312, 360, and so on.
sen.cmt: (the Chronicle of emperors)補足

sen.j: 奈良県御所市室宮山古墳（前方後円墳・全長238m）は古来「室大墓」と称され、武内宿禰の墳墓とする伝承がある。
sen.e: Muromiyayama Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound, total length 238m) in Gose City, Nara Prefecture is called 'Muro no Ohaka' from ancient times, and there is an oral tradition that regard it as the tomb of TAKEUCHI no Sukune.

Muromiyayama Tomb (a large keyhole-shaped tumulus, total length 238m) in Gose City, Nara Prefecture has been called 'Muro no Ohaka' since ancient times, and there is an oral tradition that it is the tomb of TAKEUCHI no Sukune.
sen.cmt: Added "a""tomb mound"→"tumulus""is"→"has been""from"→"since""regard it as"→"it is"
sen.e: The Muromiyayama tumulus (a circular tumulus with a rectangular frontage, with a total length of 238 m) in Gose City, Nara Prefecture, has been known as "Muro no Ohaka" (great tomb of Muro) since ancient times, and is believed to be the tomb of TAKEUCHI no Sukune in local legend.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: この宮山古墳については、その子の葛城襲津彦の墓とも言われている。
sen.e: As for this Miyayama Tomb, it is also said to be the tomb of his son, KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko, too.
It is also said to be the tomb of his son, KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko.
sen.cmt: Deleted "As for this Miyayama Tomb, ", ", too"
sen.e: It is also said to be the tomb of his son, KATSURAGI no Sotsuhiko.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: その場合、宮山古墳より少し前に造られた馬見古墳群主な古墳が武内宿禰の墓の可能性が高い。
sen.e: If that is the case, a main tomb of Umami Burial Mounds, which was made little before Miyayama Tomb, has a high possibility of being TAKEUCHI no Sukune's tomb.
If that is the case, Suyama Tomb, the main tomb of Umami Burial Mounds, which was constructed a little before Miyayama Tomb, has a high possibility of being TAKEUCHI no Sukune's tomb.
sen.cmt: Added "Suyama Tomb" from cell F33"a"→"the""made"→"constructed a"
sen.e: If that is the case, Suyama Tomb, the main tomb of Umami Burial Mounds, which was constructed a little before Miyayama Tomb, has a high possibility of being TAKEUCHI no Sukune's tomb.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: この巣山古墳の中心線は、佐紀盾列古墳群主な古墳の後円部中心を通っている。
sen.e: The center line of this Suyama Tomb goes through the center of the round part of main tomb in Sakitatenami Burial Mounds.
The center line of Suyama Tomb goes through the center of the round part of the main tomb in Sakitatenami Burial Mounds.
sen.cmt: Deleted "this"Added "the"
sen.e: The center line of Suyama Tomb goes through the center of the round part of the main tomb in Sakitatenami Burial Mounds.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 平安時代、佐紀石塚山古墳の隣りの佐紀盾列古墳群主な古墳を神功皇后の陵墓として祭っていたが、それが誤っていて祟りがあったとも伝えられている。
sen.e: In Heian Period, main tomb of Sakitatenami Tomb, which was next to Sakiishizukayama Tomb, was worshiped as the tomb of Emperor Jingu, but it has been passed down that since the tomb was not hers, people were cursed.

In the Heian Period, the main tomb of Sakitatenami Burial Mounds, which is next to Sakiishizukayama Tomb, was worshiped as the tomb of Empress Jingu, but since then it has been passed down that the tomb is not hers and is cursed.
sen.cmt: Added "the""Tomb"→"Burial Mounds""was"→"is""Emperor"→"Empress"Added "since then"Deleted "since""was"→"is"", people were"→"and is"
sen.e: According to legend, the main tomb of the Sakitatenami tumuli, which is located next to the Sakiishizukayama tumulus, was mistakenly regarded as Empress Jingu's tomb and worshipped as such during the Heian period, which incurred gods' wrath and caused plagues.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: それに従えば、神功皇后(息長帯姫)の真陵は佐紀石塚山古墳ということになる。
sen.e: If that is considered as a fact, the Sakiishizukayama Tomb must be the true tomb of Empress Jingu (Okinagatarashi Hime).
If it is true that this tomb is not hers, the Sakiishizukayama Tomb must be the true tomb of Empress Jingu (Okinagatarashi Hime).
sen.cmt: "that is considered as a fact"→"it is true that this tomb is not hers"Deleted "of Empress Jingu"
sen.e: If it is true that this tomb is not hers, the Sakiishizukayama Tomb must be the true tomb of Empress Jingu (Okinagatarashi Hime).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 『因幡国風土記』には、360歳のときに因幡国に下降し、そこで双履を残して行方知れずとなったとの記述があり、双履が残されていたとされる鳥取県鳥取市国府町には武内宿禰を祀る宇倍神社がある。
sen.e: In "Inaba no Kuni Fudoki" (records of the culture and geography of the Inaba Province), it is recorded that he came down to Inaba Province when he was 360 years old and disappeared with his sandals left there, and in Kokufu Town, Tottori City, Tottori Prefecture where the sandals are regarded to be left, there is Ube-jinja Shrine which enshrine TAKEUCHI no Sukune.

In "Inaba no Kuni Fudoki" (Records of the Culture and Geography of Inaba Province), it is recorded that TAKEUCHI no Sukune came to Inaba Province when he was 360 years old, then disappeared, leaving only his sandals, and he is enshrined at Ube-jinja Shrine in Kokufu Town, Tottori City, Tottori Prefecture, where the sandals are regarded to be left.
sen.cmt: Capitalised 'r', 'c' and 'g'Deleted "the""he"→"TAKEUCHI no Sukune"Deleted "down""and"→", then""with his sandals left there"→"leaving only his sandals"Added commaReworded last clause and moved
sen.e: In "Inaba no Kuni Fudoki" (Records of the Culture and Geography of Inaba Province), it is recorded that TAKEUCHI no Sukune came to Inaba Province when he was 360 years old and then disappeared, leaving his sandals behind; he is enshrined at Ube-jinja Shrine in Kokufu-cho, Tottori City, Tottori Prefecture, where he is believed to have left his sandals.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 他に、福井県敦賀市の気比神宮など多くの神社に祀られている。
sen.e: He is also enshrined in many other shrines such as Kehi-jingu Shrine in Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture.
He is also enshrined in many other shrines such as Kehi-jingu Shrine in Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He is also enshrined in many other shrines such as Kehi-jingu Shrine in Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 久留米市の高良大社には、高良玉垂神として祀られている。
sen.e: He is enshrined as Koratamatare no Kami in Kora Taisha Shrine in Kurume City.
He is enshrined as Koratamatare no Kami in Kora Taisha Shrine in Kurume City.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: He is enshrined as Koratamatare no Kami in Kora Taisha Shrine in Kurume City.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 皇国史観の下では忠臣の誉れが高く、日本銀行券の肖像にも、改造壹圓券（1889年）・甲五圓券（1899年発行）・丙五圓券（1916年発行）・丁貳百圓券（1942年発行）・壹圓券（1943年発行）の5種類に採用された。
sen.e: He is highly honored under Kokoku Shikan (emperor-centered historiography which is based on state Shinto), and was adopted as the portrait on 5 kinds of Bank of Japan notes, which are remodeled one yen bill (1889), Ko five yen bill (issued in 1899), Hei five yen bill (issued in 1916), Tei two hundreds yen bill (issued in 1942), and one yen bill (issued in 1943).

He was highly honored under Kokoku Shikan (an emperor-centered historiography based on state Shinto), and his portrait was used on Bank of Japan-issued one yen bill (1889), Ko five yen bill (issued in 1899), Hei five yen bill (issued in 1916), Tei two hundred yen bill (issued in 1942), and one yen bill (issued in 1943).
sen.cmt: "is"→"was""a"→"an"Deleted "which is""was adopted as the portrait"→"his portrait was used"Deleted "5 kinds of"Added "the", "-issued"Deleted "notes, which are remodeled"Deleted 's'
sen.e: He is highly regarded as a faithful retainer from the emperor-centered historical viewpoint, and his portrait was used on five different banknotes issued by the Bank of Japan - one-yen bill issued in 1889, type-A five-yen bill issued in 1899, type-C five-yen bill issued in 1916, type-D one-hundred-yen bill issued in 1942 and one-yen bill issued in 1943.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。
